author: KevinRansom
body:
Compiling F# code with crossgen I see:

Not implemented (Exception from HRESULT: 0x80004001 (E_NOTIMPL)) while compiling method basicNumberToString@860-559.Invoke
ReadyToRun: Explicit tailcalls not supported

We should ensure that .tail is supported.

Kevin

theme:tail-call

nodes.author: dsyme
nodes.body:
So I'm wondering why this is this not supported? NGEN has always supported tailcalls (at least in recent years). And there have always been many tests to ensure CLR support for tailcalls didn't regress :/ 

Do we have any info on the ramifications of this, or what's needed to support it?

Thanks

nodes.author: jkotas
nodes.body:
The fundamental problem with slow tailcalls is that we need more sane way to implement them.
- For R2R on Windows, it is needed to have a reasonable ABI that we can maintain version resiliency for. (We will fallback to JIT for them.)
- For Unix (https://github.com/dotnet/coreclr/issues/2556), it is needed to avoid writing 1000+ lines of dynamically emitted assembly code that will be a giant bug farm. (They will be turned into regular calls on Unix.)

cc @janvorli since he is going to look into this.

nodes.author: jkotas
nodes.body: We may be able to enable the fast tailcalls for R2R, but it requires teaching delay load fixups about them (the delay load fixups are not able to reliably find the indirection cell used by the tailcall - tried it in dotnet/coreclr#4984).

nodes.author: dsyme
nodes.body:
@jkotas Thanks for the details.  I have to agree that it's really, really critical for F# on .NET Core to get this sorted out - both "crossgen" and tailcalls on Unix.  

Among other things, many parts of the F# compiler toolchain itself depend on indirect tailcalls being taken, especially when processing large inputs.

nodes.author: jkotas
nodes.body:
> We may be able to enable the fast tailcalls for R2R, but it requires teaching delay load fixups about them

We should look into fixing this for .NET 5. It is becoming more of a problem.

nodes.author: VSadov
nodes.body: Is tailcalling fcalls any easier than regular methods? Or it is largely the same problem?

nodes.author: jkotas
nodes.body: It is same problem.

nodes.author: davidwrighton
nodes.body: @mangod9 I think this is too risky for .NET 5. We should fix put it on the feature schedule for .NET 6.

nodes.author: mangod9
nodes.body: yup will move.

nodes.author: dsyme
nodes.body: @cartermp Just checking, how signficant a hit is this, e.g. for F# compiler startup etc.?

nodes.author: davidwrighton
nodes.body: @dsyme I expect its fairly significant, but I don't think we would have time to ensure the right quality of fix before we fork for .NET 5.0. I hope that we can address some of these somewhat niche, and fairly small feature items early in the .NET 6 timeframe so that we can rely on the longer release process to validate the work. OTOH, if @cartermp can provide evidence that this is crucial for the release, we can address the problem.

nodes.author: dsyme
nodes.body:
@KevinRansom @cartermp Does this regress anything in the F# experience of .NET overall or is it status quo?

Just checking we're not about to encounter 6sec compiler startups except where we're already encountering them (we obviously haven't previously encountered these when using NGEN, and I _think_ .NET Core compiler only gets hit on first use?)

nodes.author: KevinRansom
nodes.body: Nothing has regressed, however, thanks to the tailcall work, done over the last year.  We have a chance at getting this fixed eventually.  I agree with David a feature over the next release to wire up the tailcall work to ready to run would be outstanding.

nodes.author: SirBogman
nodes.body: Are you sure there won't be a difference between the compiler startup time for .NET 5 with ready to run and .NET 4.8 with NGEN? Because .NET 5 won't have NGEN, correct?

nodes.author: cartermp
nodes.body:
Yes, I think nothing has regressed compared to how it has always been for F# and .NET Core. So getting this into a good place would be great, but feels like a .NET 6 kind of thing (or at least some release after 5 is out).

Since F# is already crossgen'd I don't think we're in a decent place.

nodes.author: KevinRansom
dsyme
nodes.body: Thanks all for confirming

nodes.author: TIHan
nodes.body:
This is still very much a problem - the startup time cost on the F# CoreCLR compiler is significant https://github.com/dotnet/fsharp/issues/11907
This effectively has caused us to revert the change that would allow Visual Studio to use the F# CoreCLR compiler by default.

The other option for us is to build a compiler server.

nodes.author: AndyAyersMS

nodes.author: jakobbotsch
nodes.body: I think it's ok to keep this open to track helper-assisted tail calls in R2R.

nodes.author: mangod9
nodes.body: Is there more work required for this? Or is it ok to close?

nodes.author: jakobbotsch
nodes.body: We still don't support helper-based tailcalls in R2R that this issue is actually about, but those are quite rare. I will move this to future.

title: ReadyToRun: Tailcalls not supported

author: sandreenko
body:
ReadyToRun has this optimization for a non-virtual function pointers only for now.
CoreRT supports a common case, moreover, it supports all R2R scenarios (for now the optimization is done only for `GT_FTN_ADDR` oper) where the constant lookup is used.

It would be nice to support fgOptimizeDelegateConstructor for all R2R and delete `if (IsTargetAbi(CORINFO_CORERT_ABI)) `condition there.

theme:importer
skill-level:intermediate
cost:medium

Yes, the difference is that we do not do tail call optimization for crossgen.

I think it is by design that `bool ZapInfo::canTailCall` returns false for `if (IsReadyToRunCompilation())` and the issue won't be fixed?

nodes.body: #35423 tracks R2R support for tail calls.

nodes.author: jakobbotsch
nodes.body:
Do we only run gcstress for x64/arm64 on this test? It's unclear to me why it wouldn't hit the same slowness on x86/arm32 that do not support fast tailcalls, regardless of crossgen.

FWIW we do support fast tailcalls with crossgen2 now after #56669, so this issue is probably fixed. But would like to understand why we only see the slowness with crossgen if this is due to fast tailcalls.

title: GCStress works slower with R2R on tests with deep recursion.

author: grubioe
body:
@AlexChuev commented on [Thu Aug 29 2019](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/issues/1748)

* .NET Core Version: 3.0 Preview 8
* Windows version: 1809
* Does the bug reproduce also in WPF for .NET Framework 4.8?: No
* Is this bug related specifically to tooling in Visual Studio (e.g. XAML Designer, Code editing, etc...)? No

 **Problem description:**  
Since Ngen.exe and Native Image Task are not available in .NET Core 3, ReadyToRun images are the only way to reduce the application startup time and avoid delays caused by JIT compilation. However, our tests show that for the same WPF application that initializes three times faster after using Ngen.exe, ReadyToRun images provide the difference of only 25%.  
This is a huge hit for our users, since with many libraries and theme resources, JIT compilation is one of the main factors affecting load times. For some real-life applications, the use of Ngen.exe allowed our users to shave up to 6 seconds (half) off the initial start time.
 
 **Minimal repro:**  
 You can find samples for .NET Core 3 and .NET Framework here: https://github.com/AlexChuev/ReadyToRunPerformanceTest  
 These samples use DevExpress WPF assemblies to demonstrate how Ngen.exe and ReadyToRun images affect projects with many classes and theme resources. If you need published apps or other samples for your tests, please let me know.

P.S. I'm posting this in the WPF repo because the difference between Ngen.exe and ReadyToRun images highly affects WPF applications. Normally, the JIT compiler processes classes and methods only when they are needed for the program execution. However, when WPF loads theme resources for a control, this causes all classes referenced in these resources (including classes referenced in currently unused or invisible parts) to be processed by the JIT compiler. In addition, static constructors of many WPF classes contain the DependencyProperty registration code that may cause even more classes and methods to be JITted.

---

@rladuca commented on [Thu Aug 29 2019](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/issues/1748#issuecomment-526244000)

@fadimounir Where should we file a companion bug on .NET?

---

@fadimounir commented on [Thu Aug 29 2019](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/issues/1748#issuecomment-526270416)

@rladuca Sure you can file a companion bug on dotnet/coreclr. We'd be interested in diagnosing this more, although one thing to keep in mind is that R2R by design principle will always be a bit slower than fragile native images, because they are version resilient (they do not have the same fragility as old ngen images).

> If you need published apps or other samples for your tests, please let me know.

@AlexChuev That would be very helpful

cc @jkotas FYI

nodes.author: dennis-garavsky
nodes.body:
@mangod9 @EgorBo  CC @elachlan 

**Problem**
We at DevExpress (a .NET component vendor) also experienced a related performance issue with DesignToolsServer.exe (a part of the Microsoft WinForms out-of-process designer infrastructure for .NET Core apps).
The issue is that the .NET out-of-process designer may freeze Visual Studio for 5-10 seconds, when a .NET 6+ project with third-party UI component libraries (like DevExpress and others) is being rebuilt or debugged. DesignToolsServer.exe often loads and unloads libraries with components for some reason, which causes this slowness. We are aware of known ngen/R2R performance issues in .NET 6+, and wanted to ask you to verify whether it is really related (we suspect JIT, but are not 100% sure). I also admit that DesignToolsServer.exe may potentially be changed to avoid/bypass this behavior - it may be better to show this to the Microsoft WinForms Team for review as well.

**Impact Estimate**
Real-world customer projects typically contain dozens of vendor component packages. Almost all third-party component vendors have hundreds of components in their packages (grids, editors, charts, and other UI components). Hundreds of vendor/third-party components usually reside in dozens of assemblies, and these assemblies can be hundreds of megabytes in size. This behavior may potentially affect all major/popular WinForms component vendors, including but not limited to DevExpress, Telerik, Syncfusion, Infragistics, and many others. We already received multiple reports on this from paying customers.


**Further Information**
I hope this clarifies the impact this Visual Studio/JIT behavior may have on Microsoft users and third-party component vendors/partners. If you need to get a private NuGet feed with DevExpress components for your internal testing, please email me at dennis@devexpress.com. I will also be happy to answer any additional questions/give more repro info for your .NET Core Runtime Team to improve this situation for the entire .NET developer community.  

Thanks,
Dennis Garavsky
Product Manager
dennis@devexpress.com

Hello @merriemcgaw, @elachlan and others
We tested v17.8 preview 1, but we didn't notice any significant improvements in performance. Please note that we don't have serialization issues such as this one: [https://github.com/microsoft/winforms-designer/issues/5279](https://github.com/microsoft/winforms-designer/issues/5279).

Our main point is that DesignToolsServer.exe is reloaded each time after we make changes to the code and rebuild the project. In an empty winforms project, it takes 3-4 seconds. In a project with DevExpress assemblies, it takes 8-10 seconds. At the same time, this most likely occurs because our package has a very large number of dlls that need to be loaded in a process. That is why we expect to speed up loading time with Ready2Run technology.

author: FrankGagnon
body:
In a .Net Core 3.1 application, is it possible to load ReadyToRun .NetStandard 2.0 or .Net Core 3.1 assemblies by reflection using Assembly.Load and avoid JITing when it's used? 

For context we're porting an application from .Net Framework where we used to ngen some very big assemblies we're loading by reflection in our application to avoid startup slowness. 

After some testing, it seems like there is no performance gain when loading by reflection ReadyToRun assemblies vs normal assemblies.

nodes.author: jkotas
nodes.body:
As a quick check, you can `set COMPlus_ReadyToRunLogFile=log.txt` in the environment. It will generate a log file that says whether ReadyToRun payload is used for the assemblies that you are loading.

If this does not show any issues, the next step is to run your scenario under [perfview](https://github.com/Microsoft/perfview) and see what methods are getting JITed (look for JIT Stats).

nodes.author: g-champagne
nodes.body:
(Frank's coworker) I did some tests and using COMPlus_ReadyToRunLogFile I was able to diagnose R2R. I found native image header was not found. I added the loaded by reflection assembly as a reference the project and specified "copy local" property to true, this, according to my understanding forced the assembly to be included in R2R compiling even if it's not referenced directly.

log shown native image was loaded properly, but we can't use this approach as fix because project cannot reference this assembly at build time, it's not supposed to be available yet.

To simplify problem, we have 3 projects:
Projects A1 and A2 are huge (20-40 MB each) .net standard libraries
Project B loads projects A1 and A2 assemblies at run time using reflection and invokes method using a shared interface
Both projects are compiled in separate tracks and can't reference each others at build time, this would require a major architecture change in our custom build pipeline.

Is there a way to make projects A1 and A2 compile as R2R DLLs which could be used by project B without JIT? Using readytorun config in csproj returned a warning that says only EXEs can be compiled as R2R.

Another option I would like to try if it's not possible to build R2R DLLs is to create a dummy EXE in projects A1 and A2 solutions, make it compile in R2R, then package the produced native DLLs, at build time, use MSIL DLLs and only at run time swap for the R2R DLLs. Could this work?

nodes.author: davidwrighton
nodes.body: The PublishReadyToRun property is used for publishing and producing a final shippable collection image for a complete application. As it happens your suggestion of publishing a dummy executable to use our SDK support for producing R2R images that are then manually injected into the process via an assembly load command will work, but you will likely experience problems upgrading between .NET 5 and .NET 6. I'm tagging @mangod9 here as this sounds like a scenario we should make easier to use in the future.

author: movedoa
body:
Currently ReadyToRun is disabled when isCollectible is true in AssemblyLoadContext.
This means that users have to choose between high memory consumption or bad startup performance if they load/unload assemblies as runtime.

In our case its even worse because we load and unload a lot of assemblies an undefined amount of time so our memory consumption would explode without assembly unloading.
This means that currently our performance suffers massively because we cant use r2r assemblies.

Imho there are obvious usecases for this and .NET should support this.

Also this restriction is not very obvious and i couldn't find any documentation that states that this doesn't work.
So the chance is high that many users aren't even aware of this limitation and loose performance.

See also #40683

Yes the problem definitely is in large assemblies where a lot of time is spent in the JIT.

We did a test of one of the cases we have and the difference is about ~68%.
The time of the first execution/cold start went down from 1100ms to 350ms when using r2r.

We also found out that r2r is blocked when loading an assembly from memory (#74203) which we do so we had to load from a file to do this test.

Fixing this and #74203 would (hopefully) give us a very significant performance boost although it would be conceivable that we always load from a file if there is no other way.

title: Wrong test bash script pattern for composite r2r builds

author: mjsabby
body:
## Background and Motivation

Consider a large monolithic application with a lot of managed code that needs to be JIT compiled. Furthermore, this application is running on hundreds of thousands of servers and each of these servers is redeploying this application multiple times per day. This scenario is going to (in fact already has in many cases) become more common with applications running in ephemeral containers which are shipped in pods with various lifetimes.

It is then wasteful to recompile this application on thousands of nodes. One answer to this problem is precompilation of the managed code in a build environment once and deploy this precompiled code to these thousands of servers. This does, in fact, solve most of the problems and is probably the most ideal solution.

However, it is difficult to precompile all code, and in a large application that has been precompiled a significant chunk of code (depending on the app) can still be JIT compiled.

There are various reasons why JIT compiled code will exist for most applications.

Given this, one way to mitigate the JIT compilation occurring on thousands of nodes could be if there were a cache of this JIT compiled code available at a cost significantly lower than actually JIT compiling the code. For example, a file share or database of precompiled code for that method that can mostly trivially loaded into the running program.

This desire to have a code cache then necessitates a different lifetime than the process where the code will be needed and therefore it has to be out of process.

## Proposal

The proposal is to have a system that could provide this functionality and do it in a way such that the target process could request through some mechanism the code or method to be compiled and that the compiler server can facilitate this either by storing it in some form, delegating it to a 3rd party, or actually generating the code -- or a combination there of.

## Prior Art

I'm only aware of LLVM's [Orc](https://releases.llvm.org/11.0.0/docs/ORCv2.html#features) subsystem which has similar goals to what this issue is proposing, the ability of generate code in a different process than the process where code is intended to be used in.

## Risks

Specialized niche use case & too complicated for most .NET customers.

nodes.author: JulieLeeMSFT
nodes.body: CC @AndyAyersMS, @mangod9 and @davidwrighton because this effort needs support from multiple teams.

nodes.author: AndyAyersMS
nodes.body:
cc @jkotas 

Interesting idea. (this is more of a VM issue, so will relabel).

Out of process jitting seems challenging but doable. The JIT-EE interface could be a remoting interface. The interface is fairly chatty so remoting it probably would not be very efficient, but this inefficiency might be tolerable if the results could be used to short-circuit future jitting. 

But caching JIT results and re-using them in other processes seems like it would be quite difficult. The JIT-EE interface is also stateful. JIT queries can cause side effects in the runtime, and those side effects along with side effects incurred by running code impact future queries made by the JIT. So it's not obvious how the results of jitting in one process could be shared by another process, even if they two are running the same exact bundle of managed code.

nodes.author: mangod9
nodes.body: Yeah need to determine whether the ROI is justifiable given the challenges noted above + security implications.

nodes.author: jkotas
nodes.body:
I believe that once you iterate a few times on what the caching scheme would look like, you will end up with something that looks very much like AOT image cache. The request that application issues describes the assemblies/assembly/type/method that it wants the code for, the dependencies (e.g. exact versions of the dependencies) and environment (e.g. processor model). The server sends back an AOT image that fits the bill that the application loads and wires in.

At assemblies/assembly granularity, it should be possible to build this as service independent on the runtime itself using the callbacks that the runtimes provides today.

At finer grained granularity, it would require more finer grained callbacks and probably more compact AOT format than PE files for efficiency.

For hyperscale services running a lot of code on a lot of servers, I doubt that this would deliver better results than a more traditional workflow where the AOT code is deployed from the get-go.

nodes.author: iSazonov
nodes.body:
PowerShell could be benefit from this too. It is a common scenario to run the same PowerShell scripts by task scheduler/cron. PowerShell can compile and cache script blocks but PowerShell lost the cache after its process stopped and next start is always cold. So an inter-process cache would be very useful.
It could be not only an on-memory server cache but also an on-disk cache. I saw the remark that .Net team does not plan to save a generated code to disk, however there are scenarios that will benefit from such cache that provides a warm start even after a system reboot (think about heavy-loaded workstation).

title: Out of Process JIT Compiler Server

author: jkotas
body:
The type loading involves non-trivial time-consuming algorithms such as field or vtable layout. We may be able to speed up the type loading by storing additional pre-computed information in the R2R images.

A possible design is to save just enough data to be able to build MethodTable very quickly, and teach the rest of the runtime to deal with MethodTables that do not have EEClass, MethodDescs or FieldDescs as they would be created on demand.

The data format should be [resilient](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/master/docs/design/coreclr/botr/readytorun-overview.md#version-resilient-native-code-generation) to versioning changes by default, with option to more efficiency via use of version bubbles.

Compact type layouts (CTL) was a similar idea used on Windows Phone. For inspiration, more details about CTL can be found in [Patent # 10,656,926](https://patents.justia.com/patent/10656926). 

- [ ] Estimate potential performance improvements
- [ ] Field layout
  - [ ] Investigate feasibility of creating FieldDescs lazily
  - [ ] Design format of the field layout data
  - [ ] Generate the field layout data in crossgen2
  - [ ] Consume the field layout data at runtime
- [ ] Vtable layout
  - [ ] Investigate feasibility of creating MethodDescs lazily
  - [ ] Design format of the vtable layout data
  - [ ] Generate the vtable layout data in crossgen2
  - [ ] Consume the vtable layout data at runtime

author: alpencolt
body:
According to https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/3553284bea7b650874c8dcc3f78d6be085a047bb/docs/design/features/assemblyloadcontext.md#constraints:

> If an attempt is made to load a Ready-To-Run (R2R) image from the same location in multiple load context's, then precompiled code can only be used from the first image that got loaded. The subsequent images will have their code JITted. This happens because subsequent loading binaries from the same location results in OS mapping them to the same memory as the previous one was mapped to and thus, could corrupt internal state information required for use precompiled code.

Native images will be ignored if DLL was loaded to non default context. Could you clarify why loading NI or sharing in process can corrupt runtime?

cc @jkotas @gbalykov

nodes.body: I couldn't figure out the best area label to add to this issue. If you have write-permissions please help me learn by adding exactly one [area label](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/master/docs/area-owners.md).

nodes.author: jkotas
nodes.body:
Each load context has its own copy of statics and may contain different versions of dependencies. The fixups in the R2R images point to statics and dependencies within specific context. They are not able to switch based on the load context.

For the same reason, each load context has its own copy of JITed code.

>  OS mapping them to the same memory as the previous one was mapped to

This is Windows specific behavior. On Windows, we are using OS loader to load R2R images and the OS loader does not allow one image to be loaded multiple times at different addresses. This limitation is not really there on non-Windows platforms since we have a custom loader there.

title: error NETSDK1096 with PublishReadyToRun

author: tapika
body:
Testing was done using Visual Studio 2019, v16.11.13.

According to ReadyToRun documentation - you have two alternatives to perform readyToRun images - either using project or solution. After some struggling I've decided to go with solution, maybe because it's easier to deal with nuget restore.

Ok, solution work fine - you can have ReadyToRun + linux + cli application.

But then you want to add WPF project into same solution (but still continue to use readyToRun builds).

WPF projects have:

```
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk" ToolsVersion="15.0">

  <PropertyGroup>
  ...
    <UseWPF>true</UseWPF>

```

`UseWPF` flag enabled, after which if you want to build ReadyToRun image for linux - that starts to fail with error:

```
error NETSDK1082: There was no runtime pack for Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App available for the specified RuntimeIdentifier 'linux-x64'
```

Normally you would go for blacklisting the project and add something like:

```
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk" ToolsVersion="15.0">

  <PropertyGroup>
  ...
       <IsPublishable>false</IsPublishable>
```

`IsPublishable` set to `false`.

This works fine for most of the projects, with exception to WPF projects above.

To my best understanding `ReadyToRun` performs extra steps, which are not necessary - that is nuget restore and project build, for project which does not meant to be published.

As a walkaround - developer can do following trick:

```
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk" ToolsVersion="15.0">

  <!--
    When exporting this to linux, will result in error:
      error NETSDK1082: There was no runtime pack for Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App available for the specified RuntimeIdentifier 'linux-x64'

    We reconfigure project to be empty & UseWPF disabled => then project does not reference that package, and no build error is produced.
  -->
  <PropertyGroup Condition=" ! $(RuntimeIdentifier.StartsWith('lin')) ">
    <UseWPF>true</UseWPF>
  </PropertyGroup>

...
  <ItemGroup Condition=" '$(UseWPF)' != 'true' ">
    <Compile Remove="**/*.cs" />
    <Page Remove="**/*.xaml" />
    <None Remove="**/*.xaml" />
  </ItemGroup>

  <ItemGroup Condition=" '$(UseWPF)' == 'true' ">
    <PackageReference Include="<Windows packages>" Version="xxx" />
...
  <ItemGroup Condition=" '$(UseWPF)' == 'true' ">
    <Reference Include="PresentationCore" />
    <Reference Include="PresentationFramework" />
...

```

This results in empty project, which in a turn can be successfully compiled in linux - and this will also work with windows.

`<OutputType>WinExe</OutputType>` might be also replaced with `<OutputType>Library</OutputType>` just to avoid dependency on `Main` and compilation errors.

But this sounds like tedious task for each WPF project in solution.

1. Can you recommend easier approach than my own hacky way ?
2. Would it be possible to disable building of non-published projects completely ?

author: starburst997
body:
### Description

I'm trying to build using `PublishReadyToRun` with `net6.0` in Docker (`mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/sdk:6.0-alpine`) on `linux-musl-x64` and getting this error:

```
error NETSDK1095: Optimizing assemblies for performance is not supported for the selected target platform or architecture. Please verify you are using a supported runtime identifier, or set the PublishReadyToRun property to false.
```

My Docker file look like this:

```
FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/sdk:6.0-alpine AS build

COPY . .

RUN dotnet restore -r linux-musl-x64

RUN dotnet publish --framework net6.0 -c release -o /app -r linux-musl-x64 --self-contained true --no-restore /p:PublishTrimmed=true /p:PublishReadyToRun=true

FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/runtime-deps:6.0-alpine-amd64
WORKDIR /app
COPY --from=build /app ./

ENTRYPOINT ["./MyProgram"]
```

Using this exact Docker file with `net5.0` instead works without any issues.

### Reproduction Steps

Build a C# project using this Docker:

```
FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/sdk:6.0-alpine AS build

COPY . .

RUN dotnet restore -r linux-musl-x64

RUN dotnet publish --framework net6.0 -c release -o /app -r linux-musl-x64 --self-contained true --no-restore /p:PublishTrimmed=true /p:PublishReadyToRun=true
```

Notice that it fails with the error listed above.

### Expected behavior

Since it was building fine in `net5.0` I would expect `net6.0` to be able to build it as well.

### Actual behavior

It fails with:
```
error NETSDK1095: Optimizing assemblies for performance is not supported for the selected target platform or architecture. Please verify you are using a supported runtime identifier, or set the PublishReadyToRun property to false.
```

### Regression?

Yes this is a regression, it works perfectly in `net5.0`

### Known Workarounds

It seems like I can build just fine using windows (not Docker) instead but I haven't tried running the actual output but it did compiled without any error.

### Configuration

- Which version of .NET is the code running on?

`net6.0`

- What OS and version, and what distro if applicable?

`linux-musl-x64`

- What is the architecture (x64, x86, ARM, ARM64)?

`x64`

- Do you know whether it is specific to that configuration?

Seems like I can compile just fine from windows to `linux-musl-x64` but building using Docker using `mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/sdk:6.0-alpine` or `mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/sdk:6.0` fails.


### Other information

_No response_

nodes.author: am11
nodes.body: The issue is `--no-restore`, when we pass that flag, .NET 6 SDK skips downloading the platform package which is (implicitly) required by `dotnet-publish` (on first run). Delete `--no-restore` from dotnet publish line to see if it fixes the problem.

nodes.author: starburst997
nodes.body:
Thank you very much! Yes that did work!

Still feels like a regression since it is impossible to specify to `dotnet restore` that I want it to restore with `PublishReadyToRun` so I can't have a distinct layer in my docker for restore (my docker file was trimmed down in the issue, I actually first copy only the `*.csproj`, do a `dotnet restore` then copy the rest of the files and finally do the `dotnet publish --no-restore`).

The error message is a bit misleading as well, makes it sounds like the platform cannot compile with PublishReadyToRun when in fact some files were not downloaded.

nodes.author: am11
nodes.body:
Yup, this is a regression from .NET 5 SDK, and I agree that error message is not helpful. There are three ways to overcome it:

1. `dotnet publish` without `--no-restore` (this is workaround'ish)
2. persist `<PublishReadyToRun>true</PublishReadyToRun>` and `<PublishTrimmed>true</PublishTrimmed>` properties in csproj and continue to use `dotnet restore` and `dotnet publish --no-restore` (this is more sustainable, I think)
3. `dotnet restore -p:PublishReadyToRun=true -p:PublishTrimmed=true` then `donet publish --no-restore -p:PublishTrimmed=true -p:PublishReadyToRun=true ...` (i.e. do not change project properties between `restore` and `publish`)

nodes.author: boukeversteegh
nodes.body: Same problem, and can confirm that running `dotnet restore  -p:PublishReadyToRun=true ...` before `dotnet publish --no-restore  -p:PublishReadyToRun=true ...` fixes the issue. Thanks!

nodes.author: wasabii
nodes.body: Also hitting this. My situation is worse though. I'm invoking the Publish target multiple times during a build with different options. My build process outputs multiple platform specific outputs.

nodes.author: boukeversteegh
nodes.body:
> Also hitting this. My situation is worse though. I'm invoking the Publish target multiple times during a build with different options. My build process outputs multiple platform specific outputs.

Could you share a sample of how you are currently using the restore command with multiple publish commands? I'm curious which parts are variable and which aren't, to see whether the above workaround applies.

nodes.author: wasabii
nodes.body:
@boukeversteegh 

I have projects (msbuildproj files) that use the MSBuild task to invoke the Publish target of ProjectReferences, multiple times. Each time passing different RuntimeIdentifier values. For instance, my MSI setup building project has a set of ProjectReferences, that it loops over, and invokes Publish on: once for win7-x86, and another for win7-x64, and another for win7-arm. Generating three MSIs during the build, for each Windows platform.

I have another project that invokes the three multiple times targeting Linux, to generate x86, x64 and ARM output for ultimate inclusion in Docker containers for some, and ultimately later deb and rpm builds for others.

I do this using MSBuild. Not in external scripts invoking 'dotnet'. Up until .NET 6, this worked fine, even allowing parallel builds of each of the different targets. The same project would be built in parallel for different platforms. MSBuild does that nearly automatically.

Now this is returning the error about optimization not being supported.

nodes.author: boukeversteegh
nodes.body:
@wasabii So to build your solution with .NET 6, you would have to:

- call restore for each build, turning a _constant_ restore time into _**linear**_ , over number of build targets
- and either
  - run each publish command in sequence, turning what was a _constant_ publish time into _**exponential**_
  - copy the solution for each build target and publishing in parallel, adding another **linear** operation (over solution size)

I see how this is a major regression for solutions with many projects. Hopefully it will get some attention!

nodes.author: wasabii
nodes.body: Yeah. I can't do this. .NET 6 is just off limits for me for now. Currently have a build time of about an hour. This would up it to like 6 hours or something. And I'm not going to absolutely bulldoze the way I generate MSIs and docker images just for this right now. MSBuild is supposed to work.

nodes.author: BDisp
nodes.body: I also was facing this issue and found the cause was the `sdk` version of the `global.json` pointing to a non existing runtime version. So, if the version is set to `7.0.100` and the machine only have the `7.0.102` installed, then this issue will arise. The solution is change the sdk version to 7.0.102 or install the sdk version 7.0.100.

author: alex-jitbit
body:
### Description

After upgrading nuget System.Data.SqlClient from 4.8.2 to 4.8.3 I get the above error on production: `Could not load file or assembly 'System.Data.SqlClient, Version=4.6.1.3'`

Works fine on local machine running under Visual Studio IIS Express but after PUBLISHING a "ReadyToRun" win-x64 app to a folder and then copying to the server - it stops working. 4.8.2 worked fine, it's a regression.

The weird thing is that both 4.8.3 and 4.8.2 publish the same System.Data.SqlClient.dll identical file that is 2-something megabytes large. I guess that is the problem - publishing the wrong files. Must be the "ReadyToRun" publishing messes up versioning somehow?

My guess is "ReadyToRun" publishing has some internal caching logic and does not "recompile" the file because it's not detecting any changes after moving from 4.8.2 to 4.8.3

Clearing the solution, deleting the "obj" folder before publishing resolves the problem

### Reproduction Steps

Publish a readyToRun ASP.NET 5 Core app that references SqlClient 4.8.2 in VS 2019 to a folder and try to run it. Works fine with 4.8.2. Then upgrade Nuget SqlClient to 4.8.3 and republish with readytorun - it stops working.

### Expected behavior

Should be working

### Actual behavior

Could not load file or assembly 'System.Data.SqlClient, Version=4.6.1.3'

### Regression?

_No response_

### Known Workarounds

Clearing the solution and deleting obj folders prior to publishing helps.

### Configuration

_No response_

### Other information

_No response_

nodes.author: alex-jitbit
nodes.body:
Here's the fix we use, very similar to @ltrzesniewski 's

```xml
  <Target Name="DeleteR2RCache" BeforeTargets="BeforePublish">
    <Message Text="Clearing ReadyTpRun cache" Importance="High" />
    <RemoveDir Directories="$(IntermediateOutputPath)R2R" />
  </Target>
 ```
 
Put it in your Publish Profile `.pubxml` file

author: teo-tsirpanis
body:
https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/4cc3808d9e3ad6a23fc8b0f1b167f532e9e2b067/docs/design/features/readytorun-pinvoke.md describes a mechanism where P/Invoke marshalling code for some common cases is generated ahead of time during ReadyToRun compilation.

Judging from the document this mechanism seems fragile and hard to maintain. Now that we have the `LibraryImport` source generator which is easier for ordinary R2R to take advantage of, this optimization is getting less relevant and maybe you should consider removing it for simplicity and ease of maintenance.

author: EgorBo
body:
`DOTNET_JitDisasmSummary=1` proved itself as a useful a quick (in comparison with `dotnet trace`) tool to obtain stats about JIT: how many methods are jitted, how many of those are of a specific tier, names, etc.
I propose to introduce the same for R2R code, something like this:
`DOTNET_R2RSummary=1`:
```
1: R2R used for Tables:GetBucket(int):byref:this [IL size=49, code size=294]
2: R2R used for ConcurrentDictionary`2:TryGetValue(Key,byref):bool:this [IL size=49, code size=294]
3: R2R rejected for Dictionary`2:.ctor():this [IL size=9, code size=36, reason="version is too old"]
```
with ability to log failing attempts. In theory, it can be merged with JitDisasmSummary if needed. but I'd prefer not to - currently, JitDisasmSummary prints just 7 entries for Hello World while with R2R it will be hundreds so user's code will be lost in there.

nodes.author: gfoidl
nodes.body:
> it can be merged with JitDisasmSummary if needed. but I'd prefer not to 

👍🏻 (for "prefer no to" for the reason you gave)

author: tapika
body:
### Description

When building ReadyToRun executable file, I set `RuntimeIdentifier` to `'win81-x64'` or `'linux-x64'` to determine target platform. (See [link](https://github.com/tapika/swupd/blob/master/cakebuild/commands/buildexe.cs#L100) for example)

Meanwhile - I need to variate from where to copy files as per windows or as per linux.

See following link:
https://github.com/tapika/swupd/blob/ec0f792662bdb10498bf1090b30357baf3a1d4c2/src/chocolatey/chocolatey.csproj#L69

How can I detect output build target ?

```
  <!-- 
    In normal executable - powershell modules are compiled and used to runtimes\win\lib\netcoreapp3.1\Modules
    In ready2run executables powershell modules are included from Modules - we force their inclusion into that folder.
  -->
  <PropertyGroup Condition=" $(RuntimeIdentifier.StartsWith('win')) ">
    <OSShort>win</OSShort>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <PropertyGroup Condition=" '$(OSShort)' == '' ">
    <OSShort>unix</OSShort>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup Condition=" '$(TargetFrameworkIdentifier)' == '.NETCoreApp' ">
    <None Include="$(PkgMicrosoft_PowerShell_SDK)\contentFiles\any\any\runtimes\$(OSShort)\lib\$(TargetFramework)\Modules\**">
      <Link>Modules\%(RecursiveDir)\%(FileName)%(Extension)</Link>
      <CopyToOutputDirectory>PreserveNewest</CopyToOutputDirectory>
    </None>
  </ItemGroup>
```


`RuntimeIdentifier` does not seems to work  - it works only if compiled executable is readytorun image, but not dependent assembly.

Moving conditional files copying to main executable also does not sounds as a solution - as required nuget package is only in assembly project, not in main executable.

What you can recommend to use ?

Also is there a way to detect if it's ready2run compilation or normal compilation and configure `ItemGroup Condition` to work accordingly ?

(For a demo code checkout [link](https://github.com/tapika/swupd/tree/ec0f792662bdb10498bf1090b30357baf3a1d4c2) )

### Reproduction Steps

See above.

### Expected behavior

Want to detect whether build was for windows or for linux.

### Actual behavior

Only can use fixed for either one platform.

### Regression?

_No response_

### Known Workarounds

_No response_

### Configuration

_No response_

### Other information

_No response_

nodes.author: tapika
nodes.body:
Answering to myself.

By default if you compile project as it's in Visual studio - `$(RuntimeIdentifier)` is not defined.
`$(RuntimeIdentifier)` is defined when you build ReadyToRun image.

To have some meanigful constant defined it's possible to go something like this:

```
  <PropertyGroup Condition=" '$(RuntimeIdentifier)' == '' ">
    <RuntimeIdentifier>win7-x64</RuntimeIdentifier>
  </PropertyGroup>
```

But of course then you're enforcing windows - even if you're compiling for linux.

After that condition will start to work as well

```
  <PropertyGroup Condition=" $(RuntimeIdentifier.StartsWith('win')) ">
```

I guess dotnet team could only propose how to differentiate windows versus linux, otherwise ticket can be closed.

author: rampaa
body: The [documentation](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-US/dotnet/core/deploying/ready-to-run#composite-readytorun) says that `In .NET 6, Composite ReadyToRun is only supported for self-contained deployment.` and I've mistakenly thought this meant we could use Composite ReadyToRun with FD deployment in .NET 7+ but this turned out not to be the case. After that I've tried to search for issues tracking the possible usage of Composite ReadyToRun with FD deployment but couldn't find any such issues. Thus this issue.

nodes.author: MichalPetryka
nodes.body: Composite R2R relies on all assemblies being known at build time, without SCD you can't guarantee all of your assemblies to always be the same.

nodes.author: mangod9
nodes.body: @trylek is this one of the new tests which was added as part of your cycle detection change?

nodes.author: trylek
nodes.body:
@mangod9 / @carlossanlop - This is a test issue, Crossgen2 timeout when compiling an artificially huge generic graph to exercise a cutoff parameter I added earlier this year to prevent Crossgen2 from OOMing upon such constructs. I merged in a PR slightly simplifying the test to avoid the timeouts in

https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/90777

but apparently it missed the 8.0 fork on 8/14. I don't think the test is fundamental for .NET 8 validation, after all it's just one of three tests I created for this purpose and the feature itself is rather obscure as the bug has been hit just by a few customers so far.

Carlos, can you please advise what is the most appropriate course of action here? I guess we can either send out shiproom request for backporting my PR or for excluding this test in ```issues.targets``` in the 8.0 branch. In both cases I would assume that the change is "non-product" (infra / test only) so it should hopefully fall under tell mode but I may be mistaken. For this issue, that can be marked as a test issue but that won't make the occasional timeouts in the 8.0 branch go away so it will cause a bit of long-term pain when monitoring the runs.

Thanks

Tomas

nodes.author: trylek
nodes.body: In fact it's a little weird - my PR includes removal of the issues.targets exclusion of the test that was merged before by someone, maybe Bruce but I'm not sure, when the bug started manifesting, so it should have been disabled prior to my merge of this PR. I guess in such case we should first figure out why the issues.targets exclusion is missing in the 8.0 branch - could it be a bad conflict merge?

nodes.author: trylek
nodes.body:
OK, I've found it, Bruce merged in the addition to ```issues.targets``` in

https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/90802

on 8/18 so it also missed the fork. In such case I guess a third option is to port just Bruce's PR.

### Description

When building and running `System.Threading.Threads.Tests` with `TestReadyToRun=true`, the test run will crash and fail with an error about a missing file.

### Reproduction Steps

1) Clone the repo and build the `clr` and `libs` subsets. Make sure you specify `TestReadyToRun`, so that some necessary pretest components get built.

```bash
git clone https://github.com/dotnet/runtime
cd runtime
./build.sh --subset clr+libs --configuration Release -p:TestReadyToRun=true
```

2) If PR #96721 has been merged when investigating this issue, then first reenable the test by removing its `ActiveIssue` annotation in `src/libraries/System.Threading.Thread/tests/ThreadTests.cs`:

```csharp
[ConditionalTheory(typeof(PlatformDetection), nameof(PlatformDetection.IsNotWindowsNanoServer), nameof(PlatformDetection.IsNotMobile), nameof(PlatformDetection.HasHostExecutable))]
[InlineData("STAMain.exe", "GetApartmentStateTest")]
[InlineData("STAMain.exe", "SetApartmentStateTest")]
[InlineData("STAMain.exe", "WaitAllNotSupportedOnSta_Test0")]
[InlineData("STAMain.exe", "WaitAllNotSupportedOnSta_Test1")]
[InlineData("MTAMain.exe", "GetApartmentStateTest")]
[InlineData("MTAMain.exe", "SetApartmentStateTest")]
[InlineData("DefaultApartmentStateMain.exe", "GetApartmentStateTest")]
[InlineData("DefaultApartmentStateMain.exe", "SetApartmentStateTest")]
[ActiveIssue("https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/34543", TestPlatforms.Windows, TargetFrameworkMonikers.Netcoreapp, TestRuntimes.Mono)]
// Comment this one out --> [ActiveIssue("https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/96722", typeof(PlatformDetection), nameof(PlatformDetection.IsReadyToRunCompiled))]
public static void ApartmentState_AttributePresent(string appName, string testName)
{
    var psi = new ProcessStartInfo();
    psi.FileName = DummyClass.HostRunnerTest;
    psi.Arguments = $"{appName} {testName}";

    using (Process p = Process.Start(psi))
    {
        p.WaitForExit();
        Assert.Equal(PlatformDetection.IsWindows ? 0 : 2, p.ExitCode);
    }
}

```

3) Build and run the test

```bash
cd src/libraries/System.Threading.Thread/tests
/path/to/runtime/dotnet.sh build -c Release -t:Test -p:TestReadyToRun=true
```

### Expected behavior

All tests pass, except the skipped ones.

### Actual behavior

Test fails with the following error, making the whole run fail:

```text

  [SKIP] System.Threading.Threads.Tests.ThreadTests.ApartmentStateTest_ChangeBeforeThreadStarted_Windows_Nano_Server
  [FAIL] System.Threading.Threads.Tests.ThreadTests.ApartmentState_AttributePresent(appName: "STAMain.exe", testName: "GetApartmentStateTest")
  System.InvalidOperationException : Cannot start process because a file name has not been provided.

     at System.Threading.Threads.Tests.ThreadTests.ApartmentState_AttributePresent(String appName, String testName) in /path/to/runtime/src/libraries/System.Threading.Thread/tests/ThreadTests.cs:line 178
```

### Regression?

No

### Known Workarounds

Keep the test disabled so that the other tests in the run can be executed unaffected.

```bash
git clone https://github.com/dotnet/runtime
cd runtime
./build.sh --subset clr+libs --configuration Release -p:TestReadyToRun=true
```

2) Build and run the test

```bash
cd src/libraries/System.Text.RegularExpressions/tests/FunctionalTests
/path/to/runtime/dotnet.sh build -c Release -t:Test -p:TestReadyToRun=true
```

### Expected behavior

All tests pass, except the skipped ones.

### Actual behavior


nodes.author: stephentoub
nodes.body: What does TestReadyToRun do?

nodes.author: ivdiazsa
nodes.body: It is a new mode that allows to run libraries tests compiled with ReadyToRun enabled. The original PR #75230 goes more in depth about the specifics of this mode.

nodes.author: stephentoub
nodes.body:
> It is a new mode that allows to run libraries tests compiled with ReadyToRun enabled. The original PR #75230 goes more in depth about the specifics of this mode.

I assume this issue then is about fixing that mode's handling of various things or disabling tests that for whatever reason are incompatible with it? This doesn't seem actionable from a regex perspective.

nodes.author: ivdiazsa
nodes.body:
I'm not sure I'm understanding. I was under the impression that in our product (dotnet), we should be able to run apps and get the same results, regardless of whether it is jitted or precompiled. Differences would come in size, performance, etc, but the app should return the same results. Or am I misunderstanding?

I ask because if this is not the case (me misunderstanding), then the test should be able to work under R2R as well right?

nodes.author: stephentoub
nodes.body:
However this is packaged / executed / built is doing something that's causing assemblies to behave differently. The failures here aren't coming from Regex; they're coming from Roslyn (the regex tests are loading Roslyn to test the source generator):
```
System.NotSupportedException : The language 'C#' is not supported.
   at Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Host.HostWorkspaceServices.GetLanguageServices(String languageName)
   at Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Host.Mef.MefWorkspaceServices.GetLanguageServices(String languageName)
   at Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SolutionState.AddProject(ProjectInfo projectInfo)
   at Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SolutionCompilationState.AddProject(ProjectInfo projectInfo)
   at Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Solution.AddProject(ProjectInfo projectInfo)
```

nodes.author: ivdiazsa
nodes.body: Ok I understand, thanks for the explanation Stephen. I have another question I would like to hear your opinion on. Would you consider this a bug in Roslyn and/or ReadyToRun, or would you consider it one of those cases where the test is simply incompatible and not running it is the way to go?

nodes.author: stephentoub
nodes.body: I don't know enough about what TestReadyToRun is actually doing to answer that. Can you point me to a write-up about it and/or to its implementation?

nodes.author: ivdiazsa
nodes.body: Can you help us real quick here with some deeper insight on R2R? @trylek @davidwrighton

nodes.author: davidwrighton
nodes.body: @ivdiazsa You'll need to debug the test, and see what's happening. My suspicion is that some dll isn't loadable into the process for some reason. It will probably be throwing some sort of exception from an assembly load api. You will need to identify which dll is failing to load, and preferably once you have done so, stop the whole thing in the debugger and get one of us to take a look at what is happening.

author: MaxwellDAssistek
body:
### Description

When I attempt to publish an Android project (with or without MAUI) using ReadyToRun, I get an exception while building.

### Reproduction Steps

1. Create a new Android app project.
2. Add the following to the csproj file:
```
    <RunAOTCompilation>false</RunAOTCompilation>
    <PublishTrimmed>false</PublishTrimmed>
    <PublishReadyToRun>true</PublishReadyToRun>
```
3. Run the following command: `dotnet publish -f net8.0-android -c Release -p:RuntimeIdentifier=android-arm64`

### Expected behavior

Publish should complete successfully.

nodes.author: filipnavara
nodes.body:
.NET on Android uses the MonoVM runtime. R2R is only available with CoreCLR runtime and it's thus NOT available on Android.

However, MonoVM does support [ahead of time compilation and profiled AOT](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/dotnet/performance-improvements-in-dotnet-maui/#profiled-aot).

nodes.author: MaxwellDAssistek
nodes.body: @filipnavara I am looking to dynamically load some plugins during runtime, which prevents using AOT, so I was attempting to use Ready To Run to optimize the first-load performance of these plugins.

nodes.author: filipnavara
nodes.body:
> [@filipnavara](https://github.com/filipnavara) I am looking to dynamically load some plugins during runtime, which prevents using AOT, so I was attempting to use Ready To Run to optimize the first-load performance of these plugins.

MonoVM AOT is technically closer to how CoreCLR ReadyToRun works. It still allows dynamic code. It's NOT the same as NativeAOT that has the restrictions you are mentioning.

nodes.author: MaxwellDAssistek
nodes.body:
> MonoVM AOT is technically closer to how CoreCLR ReadyToRun works. It still allows dynamic code. It's NOT the same as NativeAOT that has the restrictions you are mentioning.

I can't seem to find any clear instructions on how I can apply Mono AOT without Trimming being enforced.

nodes.author: vitek-karas
nodes.body:
@simonrozsival / @jonathanpeppers is it even possible to run the mono AOT compiler without the trimmer, I don't think that would work.

That said it should be possible to "root" everything. Maybe something like TimeMode=copy if it still works.

nodes.author: jonathanpeppers
nodes.body:
Mono's AOT compiler runs alongside the trimmer currently, so I don't know how you can use it without trimming.

See: https://github.com/dotnet/android/issues/10063

There isn't a good reason to want this combination:
* Release mode
* No trimming
* Mono's AOT

You would end up with the largest .NET Android app possible with this combination!

What I suspect the actual problem is:
* You ran into some kind of trimming issue.
* You disabled trimming completely, and that fixed it.

I would go back to enabling trimming and see if there is a problematic library causing it. You may be better off simply doing (for `MyProblemAssembly.dll`:
```
<ItemGroup>
  <TrimmerRootAssembly Include="MyProblemAssembly" RootMode="All" />
</ItemGroup>
```

You will end up with a much more reasonably sized app this way.

nodes.author: vitek-karas
nodes.body:
The plugin scenario and trimming don't play nice together, so this will be difficult to resolve either way.

That said the default Mono AOT behavior on Android should be to only AOT the startup path in the framework. So even if the assemblies themselves are not trimmed, the AOT size cost should be more or less the same. This obviously doesn't apply if the settings are enabling full AOT, that would have really big size impact without trimming.

nodes.author: jonathanpeppers
nodes.body: Oh, I missed the "plugin" comment. It would be helpful if the app knew the list of plugins at build time, but maybe that isn't possible.

nodes.author: MaxwellDAssistek
nodes.body: That's correct. The plugin architecture that we require prevents us from knowing the full list of plugins at build time. We would like to just have each module be as optimized as possible ahead of time. On desktop ReadyToRun is a great help with this.

nodes.author: vitek-karas
nodes.body:
There are two parts to this:
- Disable trimming so that plugins have a chance to work. This will be probably tricky to do since mobile in general assumes trimming. Using things like `TrimmerRootAssembly` is definitely a way to try. 
- AOT. The default AOT for Android is to AOT only the startup path in the framework, that approach should work regardless of trimming. If you want to enable full AOT, that will probably be tricky to get to work, because that again assumes trimming.

@jonathanpeppers maybe you know more about the details of this.

nodes.author: MaxwellDAssistek
vitek-karas
nodes.body: The default for Android is to AOT startup paths, that should work out of the box and AFAIK should not be affected by the trimming changes. I don't think we have another AOT options between this default setup and the full AOT - Jonathan might know if there's some way it can be achieved, but it's likely not going to be simple.

nodes.author: jonathanpeppers
nodes.body:
How are the plugins provided inside the app? Are they downloaded from the web and then loaded with `System.Reflection.Assembly`?

For AOT to work with the plugins, it has to load a native library. I think it only looks in the default locations for `.so` with the pattern of `libaot-*.dll.so`. These would either be inside the app (extractNativeLibs=false), or extracted at app install time.

I'm not sure you'll easily download and load these `.so` files dynamically at runtime.

nodes.author: MaxwellDAssistek
nodes.body: Correct. They are downloaded and loaded into a custom AssemblyLoadContext and potentially later unloaded.

nodes.author: grendello
nodes.body:
Technically, .so files could be generated at build time and downloaded during application build time (although there might be restrictions to the system loader as far as allowed locations are concerned). However, this is not allowed by the [Google Play Store rules](https://support.google.com/googleplay/android-developer/answer/9888379?hl=en):

```
An app distributed via Google Play may not modify, replace, or update itself using any method other than Google Play's update mechanism. 
Likewise, an app may not download executable code (such as dex, JAR, .so files) from a source other than Google Play. This restriction 
does not apply to code that runs in a virtual machine or an interpreter where either provides indirect access to Android APIs 
(such as JavaScript in a webview or browser).
```

The language there is a bit ambiguous, but I think that even DLL plugin files with wouldn't be allowed if downloaded from the web. 

However, they say that such dynamically downloaded code is disallowed from sources **other** than Google Play Store. It means that, in theory, you could create a [feature APK](https://developer.android.com/guide/playcore/feature-delivery) and request them dynamically from the Play Store. Once such a feature package is installed, you would probably access the DLL files as resources (e.g. with resource manager) and load them from memory, while the .so files would follow the standard patterns without any additional work required.

nodes.author: MaxwellDAssistek
MaxwellDAssistek
nodes.body: So I was able to make some progress with a few workarounds: First of all, I was able to eliminate the original exception by adding this to my csproj: The next error that I am seeing is this one: ``` C:\Program Files\dotnet\packs\Microsoft.Android.Sdk.Windows\36.0.0-rc.1.285\tools\Xamarin.Android.Common.targets(1466,3): error XALNS7015: System.NotSupportedException: Writing mixed-mode assemblies is not supported at Mono.Cecil.ModuleWriter.Write(ModuleDefinition module, Disposable`1 stream, WriterParameters parameters) at Mono.Cecil.ModuleWriter.WriteModule(ModuleDefinition module, Disposable`1 stream, WriterParameters parameters) at Mono.Cecil.ModuleDefinition.Write(String fileName, WriterParameters parameters) at Mono.Cecil.AssemblyDefinition.Write(String fileName, WriterParameters parameters) at Xamarin.Android.Tasks.SaveChangedAssemblyStep.ProcessAssembly(AssemblyDefinition assembly, StepContext context) at Xamarin.Android.Tasks.AssemblyPipeline.Run(AssemblyDefinition assembly, StepContext context) at Xamarin.Android.Tasks.AssemblyModifierPipeline.RunPipeline(AssemblyPipeline pipeline, ITaskItem source, ITaskItem destination) at Xamarin.Android.Tasks.AssemblyModifierPipeline.RunTask() at Microsoft.Android.Build.Tasks.AndroidTask.Execute() ``` Unfortunately Mono.Cecil seems to not be able to touch R2R assemblies... There is [an alternative](https://github.com/0xd4d/dnlib) that claims to be able to but I didn't pursue this further... I was able to work around this issue by expanding the exclude list to include all android libraries: Then I got this error: ``` C:\Program Files\dotnet\packs\Microsoft.Android.Sdk.Windows\36.0.0-rc.1.285\targets\Microsoft.Android.Sdk.AssemblyResolution.targets(198,5): error MSB4096: The item "obj\Release\net10.0-android\android-arm64\MYPROJECT.pdb" in item list "ResolvedSymbols" does not define a value for metadata "DestinationSubPath". In order to use this metadata, either qualify it by specifying %(ResolvedSymbols.DestinationSubPath), or ensure that all items in this list define a value for this metadata. ``` Looking at Structured Log Viewer, I see that the one pdb file is not added with the right attributes: Now, if I add the project dll itself to the exclude list, I do get a completed build, but it doesn't actually utilize ReadyToRun. --- Now if I let go building the base application with ReadyToRun and focus on my plugin library project, I have to add a custom target to force it to actually build ReadyToRun DLLs when publishing: (In addition to excluding `System.Private.CoreLib.dll` as before) This does result in the assemblies to be published with ReadyToRun (confirmed in dotPeek), however when I dynamically load these assemblies in a normally compiled base application, I still don't any indication of ReadyToRun being utilized. I think I am hitting issue #103435 which might just mean that ReadyToRun is totally broken in .NET for this plugin based approach.

nodes.author: vitek-karas
nodes.body:
I think there's a bit of confusion (admittedly we don't make this easy :-)):
- ReadToRun is an AOT technology used by CoreCLR, mono doesn't know anything about it. Unfortunately the SDK doesn't have guards to detect the mismatch and will (with some tweaks) do it regardless. R2R writes the AOT image into the managed assembly in such a way that mono will simply ignore it.
- Mono AOT is different from R2R, it produces .so files next to the assemblies (sort of) and in turn is not recognized by CoreCLR

I don't know if it's possible (or reasonable) to use mono AOT for this scenario - maybe @grendello would know how to trigger mono AOT on a single assembly (and make it work at runtime).

With .NET 10 RC1 you could try CoreCLR as well - it's in a preview for Android, where the usual R2R should work. Just set `<UseMonoRuntime>false</UseMonoRuntime>`. We would be interested if it works for you - even in this plugin scenario which is a bit special.

nodes.author: MaxwellDAssistek
nodes.body:
Ahh, I guess i forgot to write up where i got to on the Mono aot approach. My bad.

I just executed mono-aot-cross manually against all my plugin assemblies, which did produce .so files. However, when actually trying to dynamically load those assemblies, i see no indication that the aot libraries are actually used. There is no change in performance and nothing related to aot in mono logs.

Looking at the source code, I think that the issue is that the aot runtime is not initialized unless the main executable is AOTed.

https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/src/mono/mono/mini/mini-runtime.c#L4793

nodes.author: MaxwellDAssistek
nodes.body: @vitek-karas Its very exciting to see CoreCLR coming to android to help ease a lot of the mono limitations perhaps. However, I just tested it on the latest RC but my app just immediately crashes on startup with a segfault in `libSystem.Security.Cryptography.Native.Android.so` so looks like its still too raw. I'll try to narrow things down and make a separate issue about that.

nodes.author: jonathanpeppers
nodes.body:
There are a few fixes related to `libSystem.Security.Cryptography.Native.Android.so` that haven't shipped yet:
* https://github.com/dotnet/android/commits/fca76a3963c5006049f3311bc3a57b2675448350?author=grendello

nodes.author: MaxwellDAssistek
nodes.body: > With .NET 10 RC1 you could try CoreCLR as well - it's in a preview for Android, where the usual R2R should work. Just set `false`. We would be interested if it works for you - even in this plugin scenario which is a bit special. So I was able to work around the initial crashing (separate issue created), but I'm not really seeing much difference in performance between a R2R plugin and a simple one. Is there any way of concretely verifying if R2R data has been loaded for a specific assembly or if it is falling back to JIT? Also, I am unable to use `PublishReadyToRun` on the whole application since I'm getting the `Writing mixed-mode assemblies is not supported` error on another DLL that I tried to exclude but it didn't help..

nodes.author: vitek-karas
nodes.body:
The failure in PublishReadToRun is weird. It's a shame we don't write out the name of the assembly it's failing on. "Mixed-mode" assemblies typically refers to C++/CLI assemblies, but those should not really work anywhere but windows, so I'm surprised they're in a mobile app.

Also - if you built for Release configuration, R2R should be enabled by default with CoreCLR. So I would expect the behavior to be the same with or without `PublishReadyToRun` specified.

nodes.author: MaxwellDAssistek
vitek-karas
nodes.body: @jonathanpeppers - It's interesting that this fails only with PublishReadyToRun - I would expect we rewrite the assembly regardless of AOT solution...

nodes.author: Maxwell175
nodes.body: @vitek-karas The issue is simply that Mono.Cecil does not support R2R assemblies. So any assembly that need to be patched with Android Metadata stuff needs to not be R2R while it's being patched. Maybe the solution is simply to ensure that R2R generation happens after the patching.

nodes.author: jonathanpeppers
nodes.body:
There is a refactoring of the Android build that is needed for the new runtimes. There are Android MSBuild tasks that need to properly run before ReadyToRun (and ILC in NativeAOT's case).

The example above https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/109004#issuecomment-3289287540 is using a Debug (non-trimmed build)? Did you intend to use ReadyToRun there?

nodes.author: MaxwellDAssistek
nodes.body:
> The example above [#109004 (comment)](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/109004#issuecomment-3289287540) is using a Debug (non-trimmed build)? Did you intend to use ReadyToRun there?

All my builds are with trimming disabled. For that specific test I was using a custom build configuration intended to function as "Release" hence why I attempted to use PublishReadyToRun. I noticed that in that case it is forcing me to choose a specific runtime identifier, which is, of course, not right for an Android app. However, I have since tried it using the default Release configuration (with trimming disabled), which doesn't force a specific runtime identifier (good), but it still gives me that Mono.Cecil error.

author: tmds
body:
In https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/60174#issuecomment-2774564788 we found out R2R no longer happens on assemblies that have no IL due to the workaround added in https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/pull/3099.

The workaround can probably be removed and then behavior will be consistent with earlier .NET versions.

cc @dotnet/crossgen-contrib @omajid
title: Perform R2R (again) when assemblies have no IL.
